The counselor can guide the client on what to do in case of a disconnection, such as attempting to reconnect within a specified timeframe (e.g., 5 minutes). If reconnection is not possible due to ongoing connection issues or other problems, counselors should have a backup plan in place. This could involve contacting the client through alternative means, such as telephone or an alternative contact number, to continue the session and ensure continuity of care.

intent: How should virtual counseling sessions be ended?
response: At the end of a virtual counseling session, the client should end the video call when they have said goodbye. If the client decides to end the session, counselors should respect their decision and note that the client chose to end the session for their own sake. It is important to have an agreement or understanding between the counselor and the client regarding session endings to ensure mutual respect and clear communication.

intent: What are the procedure in Enrollment Strategies, Policies, and Procedures?
response:
2.1. Colleges or departments may commence enrollment immediately once course offering is already finalized.
2.2. The adviser or the enrolling officers shall decide the schedule that best fits the subjects advised for the students. All students should
be accommodated and no one should be left behind.
2.3. Students shall then be notified on the subjects they have to take this semester through any possible means. Changes or modificaion of the courses to be taken by the student is allowed in case
there are errors or discrepancies in the subjects advised/enrolled for the student prior to the confirmation of enrollment.
2.4. Confirmation or official enrollment shall be done by the Registrar, upon confirmation by the student that he/she shall continue his/ her studies, a week prior to the start of classes.
2.5. The process of a fully functional and efficient automated registra tion and online payment is considered for utilization. Payment includes tuition and other matriculation fees, requests (TOR, certification) of senior high school students, and graduate students, while the undergraduate students shall have efficient records for UNIFAST.
2.6. The University Admission Test for 1st-year entrants A.Y. 2020- 2021 will not be administered. Admission tests might be given during the middle of the semester as a follow-up procedure in the admission policy of the university.
2.7. Requirements for admission among college students may include high school grades, interviews, and schedules of examinations before the implementation of Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ).
2.8. The graduate students are required to submit an official transcript of records, authentic marriage certificate (if married), and 2X2 pictures to the Office of the University Registrar prior admission to the program.

2.2. The adviser or the enrolling officers shall decide the schedule that best fits the subjects advised for the students. All students should be accommodated and no one should be left behind.

there are errors or discrepancies in the subjects advised/enrolled for the student prior to the confirmation of enrollment.
2.4. Confirmation or official enrollment shall be done by the Registrar, upon confirmation by the student that he/she shall continue his/ her studies, a week prior to the start of classes.

intent: What is Tele-Web Counseling?
response: The adversity brought us another opportunity to learn. To ensure that Guidance and Counseling services be offered to its service user, the Philippine and Guidance and Counseling Association (PGCA) and other Counseling organizations recognize the use of technology in the implementation of its services. The TeleWeb Counseling is introduced to fill in the space of providing services in the New Normal.

intent: What are the Things to prepare?
response: 3.1.1. Hardware (computer, camera, headsets with microphones, cellphone, sim card (smart & globe), load budget) 3.1.2. Software (ready-to-upload materials of relaxing videos, stress and anger relief steps; email address-for counseling purposes only; e.g. Zoom-account for consultation and hushmail account, Facebook account) 3.1.3. Signage (do not disturb & counseling on-going) 3.1.4. Network (strong and stable internet connection; auxiliary personnel in case of referral-e.g. Psychologist, Psychiatrist, Neurologist, and other health experts)

intent: What are Phases of Virtual Counseling?
response: 3.2.1. Pre-Counseling 3.2.2. Briefing 3.2.3. Counseling process 3.2.4. Termination

intent: What Involves the process prior to the counseling process?
response:
Includes the collection of necessary details for counseling such as:
4.1. Service user information (contact number, address, and emergency contact person);
4.2. Internet provider;
4.3. Hardware (cellphone, laptop, personal computer, tablet, etc.); and
4.4. Screening of service user/client
4.5. Does the client know how to use technology?
4.6. Does the client understand the risk of technology?
4.7. What type of previous experience, did the client have in mental health?
4.8. What did the client like and dislike?
4.9. How frustrated does the client get with technology and what does the client do when they get frustrated?
4.10. What type of network to be used?
4.11. If the client is an appropriate match as a client for tele-counseling work.
4.12. Issues (e.g. online addiction)
4.13. Emotional state (e.g. high risk suicidal)
4.14. Psychiatric conditions (e.g. psychosis, medications)
4.15. Counseling appointment specifics  consist of the clients information that needs to be screened. It will be the basis of virtual counseling. These are:
4.15.1. Date of filing o Service users name
4.15.2. Age o Gender o Present address
4.15.3. Level (Senior High School/College) 4.15.4. Grade/Section (SHS) o Program/Section (College) o Contact number
4.15.5. The alternative contact number of service user
4.15.6. Hardware to be used (cellphone, laptop, personal computer, tablet, etc.)
4.15.7. Internet provider (personal Wifi, mobile data) o Emergency contact person
4.15.8. Contact number (emergency contact person)

intent: What is Briefing?
response: This phase includes the discussion of virtual counseling process such as; time, protocols, dos and donts on virtual counseling sessions, and briefing of informed consent and data privacy.

intent: In part of briefing, what time is stated?
response: each counselor should limit their time in the counseling process. The time of process includes the following 2.1.1. The counselors time needs to be emphasized to the client (e.g., 10 am  3 pm only). This can be the boundary of responding to the client. 2.1.2. Beginning of the session, the counselor is ready with the set up and needs to be present in front of the screen and/or camera when the client arrives. 2.1.3. Leeway, consider late clients at least half an hour. If the client failed to meet the given leeway, the appointment will be automatically canceled. 2.1.4. Briefing of protocols that happens prior to counseling (30 minutes). 2.1.5. Counseling process wherein the acceptable time is 50 minutes for the client and counselors common good. oLastly, the scheduling interval, the counselor should think of intervals between each client-this is to give the counselorample time to be ready in accepting new client and to regain energy in entering into a new session.

intent: What are the client breakdown protocols?
response: Protocols  includes the details (time), procedures turn takings, during clients breakdown, keywords, emerging criminal activities, what to do when the connection is cut, and how to end the session. 2.2.2. Turn takings  it is a challenge on how to take turns in virtual counseling. Make an agreement with the client who to speak as a show of respect to each other and to not preempt the flow of discussion and information. 2.2.3. During the clients breakdown  what to do? Form an agreement on the process of handling breakdown. A process must be clear to the client. The counselor may provide deep breathing techniques to place the clients emotional state at a evel that the client can express and extend his/her problems clearly. o Keywords  client and counselor must have a code word (e.g. whoa) that may be used when someone is there that may cause interruption, might as well to maintain safetyand confidentiality in terms of clients disclosures. 2.2.4. Emerging criminal activities  be prepared. As this event arise be ready with the list of organizations better suited to dealing with the situation. Establishing networks through auxiliary personnel is relevant. 2.2.5. What to do when the connection is cut?  explain to your client the protocol when this happens. As the service provider, it is best to guide your client on what to do. Give each other time to reconnect (e.g. 5 minutes). If such that it is unable to reconnect due to connection problems and other occurring problems, it is good to have a backup plan (e.g. connect with your client through other means-telephone, alternative contact number). o How to end the session? - At the end of the session, the client should end the video call when they have said goodbye. If the client feels like ending the session, make sure to have an agreement, like the coun-selor will note that the client chose to end the session for his/her sake for which the counselor respects the decision of the client.

intent: What is Dos and Donts?
response: includes the session rules in virtual counseling. 2.3.1. Accomplish the counseling appointment form. 2.3.2. The client will ensure he/she logs in from a quiet and private environment. 2.3.3. The client makes sure that the hardware to be used is sup- plied with enough battery charge. 2.3.4. The client is in their attire like being in face-to-face counsel- ing. 2.3.5. The client may like to have a soft drink to hand, but please do not bring food. 2.3.6. Any inappropriate behaviors or dressing will result in the ter- mination of the session. 2.3.7. The counselor and client WILL NOT record unless they have discussed this in detail previously. Inform your client about the recording of the session. Exceptions; techniques or activities that they can practice, make sure to discuss that they may record it but for their consumption only. They are not allowed to share it with others. 2.3.8. Messages in between sessions. Between session, contact should be used for administration purposes only (e.g., send- ing of necessary documents that may be a reference for the counseling process) and not used as an extension of thera- peutic work discussed in the session. 2.3.9. Explain to the client that counselors dont do counseling via text/SMS. And inform them that you may not be able to answer immediately. o Counselors do not accept a Facebook request of clients. To protect the counselors confidentiality. And to be objective in understanding the client and not to hear it to others in social media. Discuss it with the client that it is not your intention to disregard his/her intention to know about you, as this is part of the counselors code of ethics to maintain the counselor and client relationship (RA 9258).

intent: What is the Counseling Process?
response:
This phase focuses on the counseling process per se. The process does not differ from a face-to-face counseling session. Different techniques may be
applied to assist the client in finding the proper solution in their issues/
problems. Lastly, the Code of Ethics for Registered and Licensed Guidance
Counselor presented in PRC Board Resolution No. 05, Series of 2008 is highly
considered in the virtual counseling process, same grounds apply. The process
may include the following:
3.1. Conference  process referring to consultation with the client,
parent/guardian, and institutions personnel.
3.2. Follow-up  if the counseling process is still open and the goal has
not been achieved, the counselor needs to be updated on the status
of the client. This is will be subject to another appointment.
3.3. Referral  a process that permits the counselor to tap other profes-
sionals and experts that may help the client in such issues.

intent: What is counseling termination?
response:
This phase refers to the closing of the counseling process. This in-
cludes termination requested by the client to the Guidance Counselor, termination may be considered intentional and unintentional.
4.1. Counselor-initiated  termination that is ended by the counselor
upon achieving of set counseling goal.
4.2. Client-initiated - termination requested by the client/service user.
The termination of counseling sessions may take place upon the completion and submission of termination form. The office recognizes the right of their clients and the freedom to withdraw from the proces especially when the client feels that the process is not
applicable to his/her issues.

intent: What does it mean when a client withdraws from the counseling process?
response:
consist of the clients withdrawalfrom the counseling process. It will be the basis of virtual counseling. These are:
5.1. Service users name
5.2. Level (Senior High School/College)
5.3. Grade/Section (SHS)
5.4. Program/Section (College) 5.5. Contact number 5.6. Reason for termination
5.7. Withdrawal of involvement
5.7.1. I as the client chose to withdraw my participation from the counseling process for some personal reason. I do understand that this will mean
that I am not obliged to participate in any counseling sessions and that the counselor respects my decision. Though I am aware that this termi-
nation will not end the Guidance Office services as I am aware that their services are always open for their students.

intent: What is the Target Delivery Mode for Flexible Learning?
response: The LSPU Flexible Learning is an institutional response to the current and future challenges in instructional delivery. Using the results of the survey of the OVPAA and CIDQA Unit, flexible learning is contextually categorized: -2.1. Synchronous Online  learning is real-time via Internet 2.2. Asynchronous Online  students learn at different times and locations, no real-time interactions with Internet requirements (via LMS, discussion forum, self-guided materials, prerecorded videos) 2.3. E-Learning Offline  students are using digital learning resources package offline while NOT connected to Internet

intent: What is the definition of flexible learning?
response: 1.1 Flexible Learning is the design and delivery of programs, courses, and learning interventions that address learners unique needs in terms of place, pace, process, and products of learning. It involves the use of digital and non-digital technology, and covers both face- to-face/in-person learning and out-of-classroom learning modes of delivery or a combination of modes of delivery. It ensures the conti- nuity of inclusive and accessible education when the use of tradi- tional modes of teachings not feasible, as in the occurrence of national emergencies (CHEd, 2020). 1.2. Flexible Learning is a pedagogical approach allowing flexibility of time, place and audience including, but not solely focused on, the use of technology. Although it commonly uses the delivery methods of distance education and facilities of education technology, this may vary depending on the levels of technology, availability of devices, internet connectivity, level of digital literacy and approaches (SEAMEO).

intent: What are the guidelines for helping teachers transition to online learning?
response:
While faculty are expected to be proactive and reflective in their teaching practice in face-to-face settings, it is really challenging for them to migrate to the new teaching and learning environment. Crucial to the approaches ou
lined below is the provision of an opportunity to explore potentialities of e- learning, by establishing a complete migration learning plan, designing and de-veloping an e-learning module from the migration plan template, and translating the e-learning module to the LSPU platform. Here are some guidelines to help teachers transition to online learning: Step 1. Cluster subjects based on learning outcomes and disciplinal content.
The Faculty may conduct curriculum mapping to cluster the subjects according to the nature of the discipline. Some subjects may also remain stand-alone.
Step 2. Examine the syllabi and review course intended learning outcomes. The University Cluster Curriculum Review Committee (UCCRC) com- posed of the VPAA, CIDQA, Dean / Associate Dean, Program Coordinator, Subject Matter Expert, GAD Unit, and ITSO Unit, will examine and calibrate the soundness, appropriateness, and gender sensitivity of the identified Essential Intended Learning Outcomes.
Step 3. Complete migration learning plan template. The Migration E-Learning Course Plan should be accomplished by all faculty of each course as soon as they receive their teaching load for the incoming semester/
term. It will be submitted to the UCCRC for review and evaluation. The CIDQA Chairperson will endorse the accomplished Template to the CIDQA for recommendation to the Vice  President for Academic
Affairs (VPAA) for approval. The VPAA may approve the Migration Learning Plan Template at least two (2) weeks before the opening of classes.
Step 4. Design and develop a module from the migration plan template 4.1 LSPU Course GuideThe Course Guide is a document which serves as the learners guide in completing the course. It contains the general information about the course and what students need to pass the course. Further, it serves as a learning contract between the teacher and the students directly lifted and migrated from the OBE Syllabi.
4.2 LSPU Self-Paced Learning Module The university shall adopt the Self-Paced Learning Module (SLM) which was crafted during the Webinar Workshop. These e-learning materials, designed both for online and offline modes, are based on the essential competencies identified in a course. In the preparation of SLM, an established and unique identity for LSPU shall be adopted. Hence, its acronym could be described as: Leaning Outcomes. These pertain to the identified high essential learning competencies lifted from the OBE course syllabus that the teacher wishes students to perform after finishing the learning
course or unit.
Student Learning Strategies. Flexible learning is self-paced and self- directed, the IMs to be produced shall characterize as personalized learning by using it as a tool to adapt to student capabilities. The teacher determines the approach for achieving the learning objectives and are included in the pre-instructional activities, and lesson presentation adopting flexible learning options. Performance Tasks. These are the activities that require the learners to perform the task or activity to standards. It will give students an experience for engagement attuned to the community of practice. Understanding directed assessment. Assessment is done through faculty marked exams, portfolios, reflective/synthesis papers, research papers, projects, and innovative tools, among others. Step 5. Google Classroom will be institutionalized as primary LSPU LMS platform and parameters on its use to support course delivery will bemade available to faculty.

intent: What is a modified grading policy?
response:
The Modified Grading Policy During the pandemic, shall be observed:
4.1. The university will continue using the numerical grading system for
all students;
4.2. In preparation for the non-face-to-face conduct of teaching and learning, the university shall still adopt the grading system stated in the Student Handbook.
4.3. The bases for the computation of grades used in the grading system for each grading period may include quizzes, recitation/participation, course requirements, activity sheets/projects. However, the New Normal permits the academic community to modify each grade. Hence, based on the online Self-paced Learning Module, the following components for the computation of grades shall be adopted:
4.3.1. Synchronous/Asynchronous: Course discussion  20%; Ac-tivities/Performance Task 40% Final Exam /Outputs 40% 4.3.2. E-learning Offline/Remote Modular: Activities/
Performance Task 50%; Final Exam/Outputs  50% The Offices of Graduate Studies Applied Research shall determine the parameters for the assessment of their students' academic performance, taking into consideration the current situation.
4.5. The GSAR may also adopt the grading system for undergraduate students.

intent: What does it mean to safeguard the integrity of assessment?
response: 5.1. Assessment of learning outcomes, regardless of the mode of learning and teaching will follow the requirements and standards that have been developed by the faculty and adopted by the University. 5.2. These requirements and standards will be uniform and not vary across different courses regardless of the degree of flexibility they may integrate as part of the learning and teaching transaction in any mode of study. 5.3. All formal course examinations taken by students, as part of any mode of study, will be proctored and may be taken online. 5.4. Course work and assessment items undertaken and/or submitted online will be authenticated with procedures and processes, in- cluding tools such as Turnitin, to ensure that all online learning activities are valid and undertaken by the registered student. 5.5. Student Manual may be revisited regarding the rules on cheating and its consequences. 5.6. Students may sign an Honesty Form where students commit thatThe answers came from them without relying on others and with knowledge of consequences when caught dishonest, and attested by parents, if possible. 5.7. Students may sign a Non-Disclosure Agreement attested by the parents to minimize the spreading of the assessment tool.

intent: What are quality assurance measures in an educational context?
response: Monitoring, Review, and Assessment of Instructional Materials 1.1. The University Curriculum and Instruction Development (CIDQA) Unit of each campus will review, assess, and monitor the rules, policies, and guidelines in the adoption of the flexible learning delivery mode to ensure the safety of students, faculty members, and employees from the pandemic. 1.2. The CIDQA shall establish criteria for the assessment of self-paced learning materials or learning resource materials to check The language construction, comprehensibility of the learning contents, intellectual property rights, gender sensitivity, and creativity in the presentation of ideas and design. 1.3. The creation of the University Cluster Curriculum Review Committee (UCCRC) will provide faculty developers assistance and guidance in the preparation of learning materials on the different area of expertise, including but not limited to: Agriculture, Fishery, Forestry; Business Administration and Related Areas; Education Sciences and Teacher Training; Engineering and Technology; General Education; TVL (HE, Trade, Industrial); IT Related Discipline; Law and Jurisprudence; Mathematics; Natural Sciences; Behavioral Sciences; Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences; Physical Education; and Languages.

intent: What is the University Cluster Curriculum Review Committee (UCCRC)?
response: The UCCRC composed of the VPAA, CIDQA, Dean/Associate Dean, Program Coordinator, GAD Unit, ITSO Unit, and Subject Matter Expert is responsible in monitoring and calibrating the instructional materials prepared by faculty. The functions of the UCCRC are the following: 2.1. Vice President for Academic Affairs  approves the IMs prepared by the faculty prior their publication, circulation, and utilization ordinator and subject matter experts in the College. He/she also certifies and endorses the IMs to CIDQA for evaluation. 2.5. Program Coordinator  evaluates the organization and presentation of the instructional material and the suitability of the assessment procedures 2.6. Subject Matter Experts  examines the IMs in terms of learning content, format, and language construction 2.7. GAD Unit  verifies the inclusivity and gender-sensitivity of the instructional materials developed by the faculty 2.8. Innovation and Technology Support Office (ITSO)  checks and certifies the intellectual property right of the IMs 2.2. CIDQA Director  validates the reviewed IMs prior its endorsement to VPAA for approval 2.3. CIDQA Chairperson  coordinates with the CIDQA Director, Deans/Associate Deans, Program Coordinators, and Subject Matter Experts regarding the evaluation of the IMs. He/she issues the signed approval sheet to the faculty. 2.4. Dean/Associate Dean  supervises and motivates the faculty to develop instructional materials. He/she identifies the program co-

intent: What does monitoring faculty presence mean in the context of ensuring quality learning?
response:
Faculty presence shall be monitored in two ways depending on the level of community quarantine declaration: (1) when residential instruction is allowed, faculty attendance will be monitored by their presence in their respective classes; and (2) when the community quarantine declaration requires students to stay at home, faculty presence shall be monitored through a progress report on the achievement of their students through thehome or distant learning using the learning modules.
The following documents shall be submitted by the faculty at the end of each month. They shall be used as proof that services are rendered by the faculty:
3.1. Pilot Testing Results of the Self-paced Learning Module through the Survey Questionnaire accomplished by all students enrolled in the class (LSPU  CQA  SF  011). (See Annex A)
3.2. Accomplishment Report that documents the classes being conducted synchronously or asynchronously/e-learning offline OR
Students Progress Report, of all classes handled, if the mode of instructional delivery is purely home or distant learning using the printed module; and
3.3. Faculty Daily Time Record, when limited face-to-face instruction is taking place.
3.4. Before the semester ends, the teaching effectiveness of all faculty will be gauged through LSPU  CQA  SF  012 (Criteria for
Evaluation of Teaching Effectiveness in Flexible Learning) to be accomplished by at least 10 students (through the Program Coordinator), Dean/Associate Dean, CIDQA, and VPAA.

intent: What is an internship/practicum?
response: University Policy on On-the-job Training (OJT)/Practicum/Internship 1.1. No student shall return to their respective field to continue with their OJT/Practicum/Internship. 1.2. The incomplete period/time accomplished by the student for OJT/practicum/internship may adopt alternative learning opportunities to be used for implementation and assessment in the completion of the supposed exposure. 1.3. Where it is applicable, the final task regarding OJT/practicum/ internship may make use online and live video presentations (e.g., via Zoom) duly arranged by the teacher-in-charge/adviser for proper management and assessment (e.g., final demonstration for education). 1.4. For courses with the required number of hours of OJT/ practicum/internship such as B.S. Nursing, the college may opt for the inter-semester hours to complete the essential subject re- quirements, and adjustments are made for other subjects to be taken in other semesters (Curriculum Shift, CHED 2020). 1.5. In recognition of the uniqueness of each college/department, any exceptional cases wherein the abovementioned procedures for OJT/practicum/internship are not applicable, may be consultedand deliberated with the Academic Affairs Office. 1.6. A work-from-home scheme could be adopted, that is, OJT/Internship/Practicum of students could be done inside the University campus. The campus could establish a simulated workplace(e.g., offices, physical plant and facilities for engineering students,etc.). However, using a virtual laboratory equipment would cost so much, hence, it shall be advised that the focus of the first term of the curriculum contents would be on theories, concepts, and principles. The second semester would see to the applications of those skills and a request for an extension of laboratory hours shall be allowed.

intent: What is the purpose of conducting research and extension/production in an educational institution?
response:
In view of the on-going COVID-19 pandemic particularly with the imposition of the Modified General Community Quarantine in the province of Laguna by the national government, faculty researchers and extensionists are
dvised to be guided with the relevant protocols and guidelines that were issued by the Inter-Agency Task Force and the Office of the University President in the conduct or implementation of their respective research and development-related activities. This is to ensure for the safety and of the other university personnel and the public, in general, during this health crisis. Specificconcerns regarding the implementation of the duly approved research programs/projects/studies at this point in time can be directed to the Office of the Director of Research and Development via email atrd_siniloan@lspu.edu.ph. (LSPU-RDOMEMO-006; October 13, 2020). Research Development at the present time is much needed and inevitable. In the light of the existing National Health Emergency Situation in the country, LSPU must be proactive in innovating measures that will support the fight against COVID 19. Sustainability of LSPU RDE work is deemed necessary specifically during and after the ECQ, hence submission and screening policies which are fitting to the situation are to be put in place to accelerate andl ikewise achieve the Universitys RDE targets.
Relative to this, an alternative work arrangement such as work from home scheme (CSC Memo Circular 10, s. 2020) is to be followed in the imple-mentation of the following rules and policies in research and all project works
discussed herein.

intent: What is the process for submitting research and extension proposals?
response: To amplify the efforts of LSPU research and extension faculty in the different Units and Colleges which were affected by the implementation of ECQ, a flexible schedule and shortened protocol in the submission and screening of research proposals is recommended, hence the following rules and policies must be observed: The process for submitting research and extension proposals may vary depending on the institution or funding agency. Typically, it involves the following steps: 1.1. Submission of Research and Extension proposal must be held open to all faculty who are interested in submitting RDE proposals for screening during and after ECQ. Submission and screening will be done in two rounds (batch 1 and batch 2) based on a proposed schedule. 1.2. A shortened time in the submission and screening (utmost one month from date of submission) will be observed based on a new recommended RDE protocol: 1.3. It is to be noted that no in house review shall be called to proceed, instead review must strictly be made through blind review of internal experts in specialized field where research is categorized and blind review of external expert to be done through email and online consultation if necessary. 1.4. Further, in consideration of the urgency to respond to the most pressing problems brought about by COVID 19, the LSPU has to take the lead in developing research innovations in areas of its expertise. Such that, in addition to the usual call to undertake research in the University, it is important that a shift from the normal to the NEW Normal way of prioritizing innovation and increasing support thereof, must be shaped through forwarding the following protocol in doing research innovation:

intent: What are the rules and policies regarding participant eligibility for capacity building programs during and after ECQ?
response:
To minimize movement and face to face interactions, the following guidelines are hereby set for implementation:
2.1. In exchange of the normal face to face training workshops for capacity building of RDE faculty, open learning programs must be designed using tools that utilize media with the following recommended content:
 Training Guide Roadmap
 Content of Training Course
 Course Pack containing all instructions for the training
 Online References, websites and video references 2.1.1. Relative to this no capacity building workshops shall be carried out without an approved training module, training
resources and attached schedule of activities and training proposal for this purpose.
2.1.2. Narrative Report of capacity building Activities shall be submitted with the following attachments (Certificates of Attendance, pre-test and post-test evaluation report, narra-tive report with photo documentation, list of Participants, copy of the training module. sample of training output)
2.1.3. To sustain the efficient performance of all faculty in RDE each RDE coordinator, chairperson and director will required to submit one training module and conduct one online capacity building activity based on the need of LSPU faculty during and after the ECQ implementation. The following topics for Modules to be used for capacity building activities which may be done simultaneously to this effect is hereby recommended: All LSPU faculty are encouraged to submit online RDE training materials and learning tools that utilize media resources as mode of transfer to clientele (e.g., videos, distance education modules, RDE support systems, or any form of open learning programs) based on their expertise.The said learning resources once approved will be credited as RDE contribution and accomplishment of thefaculty concerned.

intent: What are the Rules and Policies in the Conduct of Extension Projects During and After ECQ?
response:
Guided by Office Memorandum series 2020, dated March 12 from the University President regarding cancellation and postponement of campus activities, all Extension and Community activities shall be in abeyance until further order is issued from the Office of the University President. 3.1. All extension activities (e.g., Relief Operations) which are voluntarily conducted as part of the Universitys initiative to combat COVID shall be recognized as RDE accomplishment of all faculty engaged in the activity.Relative to this, terminal report of activities with photos and list of beneficiaries shall be submitted to the ETS Office for official documentation.
3.2. All relevant RDE undertakings that will meaningfully contribute to combat COVID 19 and to mitigate its effect to society and communities may only be implemented upon request and approval of the University president. 3.1. All extension activities (e.g., Relief Operations) which are voluntarily conducted as part of the Universitys initiative to combat COVID shall be recognized as RDE accomplishment of all faculty engaged in the activity. Relative to this, terminal report of activities with photos and list of beneficiaries shall be submitted to the ETS Office for official documentation. 3.2. All relevant RDE undertakings that will meaningfully contribute to combat COVID 19 and to mitigate its effect to society and communities may only be implemented upon request and approval of the University president.

intent: What are health and safety protocols?
response: LSPU is committed to ensure safe educational continuity amidst the challenges of the pandemic. Learning opportunities must be provided to give hope and stability, contribute to the normalization of activities in the country, and facilitate development of our learners and bring normalcy to their lives.

intent: What are general guidelines?
response: 1.1. LSPU shall adopt the new norms of physical distancing and safety measures to prevent the transmission of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). Number of people in the workplace shall be reduced, as well as the need to travel, including work from home arrangements to those whose tasks can be done at home, andamong employees at high risk (employees beyond 60 years of age or of any age with comorbidities, or pre-existing illness such as hypertension, diabetes, cancer/immunocompromised health status, or with high-risk pregnancy). 1.2. LSPU shall screen returning employees/workers for influenza-like symptoms. Temperature checks and proper disinfection of inbound and outbound persons must be strictly implemented. 1.3. On-site classes, sports and other extra-curricular activities shall remain suspended until further notice from the proper authorities.

intent: What are specific guidelines?
response:
1. 1. Administrative Control Measures
1.1.1. Workspaces should be properly and regularly disinfected, ventilated, and maintained.
1.1.2. Putting of proper visual reminders for safety policies in strategic locations in the University to improve compliance.
1.1.3. Adoption and implementation of alternative work arrangements indicated in the Civil Service Commission Memorandum Circular 10, series of 2020.
1.2. Implementation of Other Prevention and Control Measures
1.2.1. There shall be health service personnel at the main gate to conduct daily temperature and symptom monitoring and recording of all employees who report to work. The health units are to submit weekly reports, or as the need arises to the Campus Director of their respective campus. They are to refer/report to RHU any probable or suspected case of COVID-19.
1.2.2. Enforce infection control procedures such as:
1.2.2.1. physical distancing of one (1) meter, including in workspaces; 1.2.2.2. mandatory wearing of face masks and face shields, especially those involved in frontline services; 1.2.2.3. all persons entering the University shall pass through the Sanitation Tent or Campus Observation Tent located at the main entrance; 1.2.2.4. All vehicles shall pass through the sanitation area upon entering the University premises; 1.2.2.5. No persons are allowed inside the University without proper authorization especially during weekends and holidays; 1.2.2.6. Availability of handwashing and/or sanitizing stations, alcohol/sanitizer dispensers to promote meticulous hand hygiene (all employees should be advised to at least bring with them alcohol or hand sanitizer to be used even when they are no longer in the University premises); 1.2.2.7. There shall be a supervision of all sanitation and disinfection procedures (especially railings, door- knobs, etc.,); 1.2.2.8. Provision for the installation of pin microphone and speaker to all transaction windows; and 1.2.2.9. In the meantime, flexible teaching and learning shall be the primary mode of learning for students. Once on-site classes resume, the number of classes should be reduced and staggered days should be imple- mented to enable students and teachers to comply with physical distancing and other safety measures.

intent: What is the Crisis Management Committee (CMC) at LSPU?
response: LSPU has created a Crisis Management Committee (CMC) for each campus.

intent: What is the purpose of the communication plan developed by LSPU?
response: LSPU has developed a communication plan to provide timely and updated information to all stakeholders.

intent: Does LSPU have isolation facilities on its campus?
response: Yes, LSPU has a standby set-up of a single-person isolation room in its campus clinic or health service area.

intent: How has LSPU ensured the dissemination of information regarding health protocols and precautions?
response: LSPU has conducted virtual orientation and disseminated information, Education and Communication Materials detailing health protocols, precautions and/or FAQs to students, faculty, and staff who will be allowed to attend face-to-face classes.

intent: What guidelines does LSPU's health and safety plan follow?
response: LSPU has a health and safety plan based on DOH and CHEd guidelines.

intent: What measures has LSPU taken to ensure visibility and communication of health safety information?
response: LSPU has put/posted visible, readable, and adequate number of signs and signals in each campus.

intent: Are there policies in place at LSPU regarding the use of personal protective equipment (PPE)?
response: Yes, LSPU has policies/protocols on the use of PPEs, as recommended in DOH Administrative Order No. 20200015.

intent: What facilities are available at LSPU to promote handwashing and sanitation?
response: LSPU has handwashing facilities and an adequate supply of sanitation products to be placed in strategic places

intent: How does LSPU ensure the observance of physical distancing, physical hygiene, and environmental hygiene?
response: LSPU has put up engineering controls to ensure physical distancing, physical hygiene, and environmental hygiene are observed.

intent: Does LSPU have a mechanism for contact tracing?
response: Yes, LSPU has a mechanism by contact tracing, following rules and regulations of DOH.

intent: Are there emergency transfer protocols at LSPU?
response: LSPU has emergency transfer protocols, in case a student, faculty, or staff exhibits signs and symptoms while within the campus.

intent: can LSPU handle COVID-19 suspects and confirmed cases?
response: LSPU has referral system protocols for COVID-19 suspects and confirmed cases.

intent: How does LSPU ensure appropriate learning options for students and capacity building for faculty?
response: LSPU has conducted a needs assessment of students and faculty to appropriately determine appropriate flexible learning option/s and capacity building training for them, respectively

intent: What is the Learning Continuity Plan at LSPU?
response: LSPU has a Learning Continuity Plan ensuring academic quality and equity.

intent: What does LSPU's Student Affairs and Services (SAS) Plan entail?
response: LSPU has a Student Affairs and Services (SAS) Plan ensuring continuous provisions of supporting holistic development of students

intent: Are all faculty members at LSPU capable of implementing flexible learning?
response: Yes, All faculty of LSPU are capable and ready to implement flexible learning.

intent: What is the role of the Crisis Management Committee (CMC) at LSPU in relation to COVID-19?
response: Sec.1. LSPU has a Crisis Management Committee (CMC) whose main function is to take the appropriate measures when risks and impacts of COVID  19 may exist in the campus or community, e.g., presence of suspected and confirmed cases have been reported. The LSPU CMC is in charge of communication or information dissemination.

intent: Who are the members of the LSPU CMC?
response: Sec. 2. The LSPU CMC is composed of the University President, Vice-President for Administration, Campus Director, Planning Officer, and University Health Officer who is responsible for ensuring adherence to safety regulations, rules and policies, and for assessing unsafe act and environment, and hazardous situations/circumstances in the campus.

intent: What is the role of the University Health Officer in the LSPU CMC?
response: Sec. 3. The CMC shall determine areas where students, faculty, and staff congregate, and recommend measures to be undertaken by the school so that the congregation can be avoided or if necessary, to education, minimized.

intent: Who is responsible for recommending and implementing closures of physical classes?
response: Sec. 4. The CMC shall recommend and implement closures of physical classes if there will be clustering of suspected cases in the classrooms, laboratories, libraries, cafeterias, dormitories, or other communal areas or at least one confirmed case of COVID  19.

intent: What does the emergency response plan and continuity of operations plan entail?
response: Sec. 5. The CMC shall develop an emergency response plan and a continuity of operations plan including relevant guidelines, and procedures.

intent: What procedures are outlined for students, faculty, or staff with COVID-19 symptoms or feeling unwell?
response: Procedures when students, faculty, or staff were reported to have symptoms of COVID-19 or not feeling well in any way.

intent: How does the plan address the reporting of COVID-19 cases?
response: Reporting of cases in accordance with RA 11332 otherwise known as Mandatory Reporting of Notifiable Disease and Health Events of Public Health Concern Act and coordinating with the appropriate public health authorities whenever necessary.

intent: What measures are in place for close monitoring of suspects or confirmed cases?
response: Close monitoring of the suspects or confirmed cases and Contact tracing, among others

intent: What is the role of the CMC in coordinating with government agencies or entities for regional level guidelines on resurgence protocols?
response: Sec. 6. The CMC shall coordinate with the appropriate government agencies or entities for regional level guidelines on resurgence protocols.

intent: What are the health and safety protocols that need to be followed when entering the University premises?
response: What are the health and safety protocols that need to be followed when entering the University premises?

intent: What should students, faculty, and staff with fever or flu-like symptoms do?
response: Students, faculty, and staff who have fever or with flu-like symptoms are advised not go to the school premises. LSPU shall monitor their health status.

intent: What measures will be taken for affected students to continue their learning?
response: For continuity of learning, LSPU shall implement the appropriate flexible learning mode for the affected students.

intent: Can faculty and staff work from home if they are affected by fever or flu-like symptoms?
response: The LSPU shall allow work from home arrangement for the affected faculty and staff.

intent: When should I wear face masks and face shields?
response: Wear face masks and face shields at all times.

intent: What is the LSPU-HSU1 form, and when do I need to accomplish it?
response: Accomplish daily the health declaration form/health symptoms questionnaire (LSPU-HSU1) and submit to the guard or designated officer prior to entry. Have their temperature checked and recorded in the health symptoms questionnaire

intent: What happens if I have a temperature of 37.5 degrees Celsius and/or above?
response: For any student, faculty, staff, or guest with temperature of 37.5 degree Celsius and/or above, even after a five-minute rest, or if their response in the questionnaire needs further evaluation by the designated employee or staff, said person shall be isolated in a specific area identified by LSPU inside the holding area, and shall not be allowed to enter the premises. Close coordination with LGU/RHU shall be done to ensure that the student, faculty, staff, or guest concerned will be attended to as provided under DOH Guidelines on persons manifesting symptoms.

intent: What does the LSPU aim to achieve regarding entrance gates at the campus?
response: The LSPU shall ensure that there are no choke points at all entrance gates of the campus. There shall be adequate number screening stations to avoid long queues outside the school premises.

intent: How does the LSPU plan to avoid long queues outside the school premises?
response: Social distancing and no contact policy shall be strictly observed.

intent: What policies should be strictly observed regarding social distancing and contact?
response: Individuals who had passed the screening shall be subjected for disinfection.

intent: What happens to individuals who pass the screening process?
response: What happens to individuals who pass the screening process?

intent: What should guests/visitors go upon arriving at the University premises?
response: Guests/visitors shall be at the holding area to be assisted by the officer-in-charge as they wait for the person to be visited or be given clearance to enter the University premises.

intent: What factors does the LSPU consider when identifying classrooms/laboratories to be occupied?
response: The LSPU shall identify the classrooms/laboratories to be occupied considering foot traffic, fresh air ventilation, and near the toilets or handwashing facilities, among others.

intent: How does the LSPU assess classroom/laboratory ingress and egress?
response: The LSPU shall be able to assess classroom/laboratory ingress and egress with 1.5 m. Physical distancing to determine impact on the time needed for student movement between classrooms and buildings.

intent: The LSPU shall be able to assess classroom/laboratory ingress and egress with 1.5 m. Physical distancing to determine impact on the time needed for student movement between classrooms and buildings.
response: The LSPU shall require students to go straight to their assigned rooms upon entry to the campus.

intent: How does the LSPU limit human intersection and contact within the campus?
response: The LSPU shall implement a one-way human traffic system to limit human intersection, contact or interaction. There shall be markings on the floors indicating the directions and proper distancing to follow from the entrance gate to the room and within the room. The LSPU may employ other traffic system as long as the same will limit human intersection, contact, or interaction.

intent: Are students allowed to change classrooms between classes?
response: To limit the movement of students, the faculty shall be the ones to enter and leave the room or move between rooms. The LSPU should schedule classes so that the students will not have to change rooms, unless extremely necessary. Students can take bathroom breaks and shall be reminded to practice proper personal hygiene before returning to the room.

intent: How frequently are classrooms/laboratories sanitized?
response: The classroom/laboratory room shall be sanitized every after each use.

intent: What policies does the LSPU enforce regarding personal belongings and object handling?
response: The LSPU shall enforce policies on no sharing of personal belongings and to minimize handling of objects and touching of surfaces, unless necessary. Proper handwashing shall be done, if the situation is unavoidable.

intent: Will there be an adequate supply of sanitation products in the classrooms/laboratories?
response: Yes, There shall be adequate supply of sanitation products in the classroom/laboratory.

intent: What is the purpose of scheduling laboratory classes strategically?
response: Laboratory classes shall be scheduled strategically so that there is a one is to one student-equipment ratio.

intent: Can I bring my own food, utensils, and water bottle?
response: The LSPU students are encourage to bring their own food, utensils, and water bottle. They are allowed to eat in lecture rooms to avoid crowding the eating areas.

intent: Can I eat in the lecture rooms?
response: There will be rotating and shorter break times to minimize the number of students taking a break at the eating areas or student Halls/study centers.

intent: How should physical distancing be observed in eating and communal areas?
response: The 1.5 m physical distancing shall be observed in the eating and other communal areas. Tables and chairs are marked X to inform students where not to sit.

intent: Will there be a physical distancing enforcer present in communal areas?
response: There shall be a physical distancing enforce present at these communal areas.

intent: Are there enough hand washing stations in communal areas?
response: Yes, There shall be an adequate number of handwashing stations in these communal areas.

intent: What is the purpose of screening and registration for students, faculty, and staff before using the sports facilities?
response: There shall be screening and registration of students, faculty, and staff before they will be allowed to use the sports facilities.

intent: Will there be a time limit imposed on the usage of sports facilities for students, faculty, and staff?
response: The LSPU shall impose a time limit for students, faculty, and staff on how long they can use the sports facilities.

intent: What is the basis for determining the occupancy capacity of sports facilities?
response: The occupancy capacity of the sports facilities shall be determined following the physical distancing protocols.

intent: What types of sports or activities are allowed under the given guidelines?
response: Only non-contact sports/activities are allowed as long as physical distancing and contact precautions are strictly observed. Thus, contact sports such as basketball, volleyball, and soccer are not allowed.

intent: How often should cleaning and disinfection be carried out in sports facilities?
response: Cleaning and disinfection of the gym, sports facilities, and chang[1]ing rooms, among others shall be performed more regularly and frequently

intent: What safety measures are in place at the facilities mentioned?
response: There shall be hand hygiene stations at entrance and exit points of these facilities, establish a one-way circulation of individuals through the facilities and limit the number of persons allowed in the locker room at one time, based on physical distancing protocols.

intent: What are the library services provided in LSPU?
response: 6.1. Students, faculty, and staff need to wash or sanitize their hands before entering. Sanitation products or handwashing stations shall be available at the entrance of the library. 6.2. There shall be body temperature screening before a student, faculty, or staff can enter the library. 6.3. Students, faculty, and staff need to register their names, time-in, and time-out in case contact tracing will be needed. 6.4. Tables and chairs are marked to inform the students, faculty, and staff were not to sit. 6.5. 1.5 m physical distancing shall also be strictly observed inside the library. 6.6. The LSPU shall determine the maximum time limit a student, faculty, or staff can stay inside the library and the number of times he or she can access it per day. 6.7. There shall also be quarantine protocols for returned books or materials. 6.8. Commonly shared computer units shall be disinfected before and after use. 6.9. As much as possible, LSPU shall encourage students, faculty, and staff to use the online library services instead of actually going to the library. LSPU shall promote the PhlCHED Connect for free access to instructional and learning resources or materials.

intent: What is the policy regarding LSPU leaving the campus?
response: 7.1. Students, faculty, and staff shall leave the campus on the designated time. They cannot stay longer than necessary inside the campus. 7.2. There shall be a designated exit gate. Students, faculty, and staff can only pass through this gate to leave the campus. 7.3. Students, faculty, and staff shall be constantly reminded on how to be safe on their way home.

intent: What are LSPU simulations and drills?
response: 8.1. LSPU shall conduct simulations and drills of traffic flow and 1.5 m physical distancing for a smooth implementation of controlled traffic of students, faculty, and staff. 8.2. LSPU shall have a plan how to conduct fire and earthquake drills while still maintaining 1.5 m physical distancing. 8.3. LSPU shall have enforcers of physical distancing deployed around the campus to monitor and ensure said measure is strictly observed.

intent: What is the purpose of the LSPU School-Based Isolation Room for Persons with Flu-Like Symptoms?
response: 9.1. When students, faculty, and staff develop flu-like symptoms while in school premises, they shall be immediately confined in an isola[1]tion room while waiting to be transported to a health facility or to home. 9.2. Students, faculty, and staff who developed flu-like symptoms while at school should be evaluated by the CMCs appointed medical or safety health officer. This officer must be familiar with: 9.2.1. How disease spreads; 9.2.2. How to identify disease symptoms; 9.2.3. How to protect themselves; 9.2.4. Environmental cleaning and disinfection procedures; and 9.2.5. When to contact health official or occupational health services. 9.3. If a student, faculty, or staff becomes ill, 9.3.1. If symptomatic, he or she shall be placed in a single  person room with the door closed. He or she shall have access to a dedicated bathroom. 9.3.2. If asymptomatic, the CMC shall designate isolation rooms that have outside access or exit doors to facilitate transport of student, faculty, or staff without contaminating additional school areas and limiting his or her exposure to others. 9.3.3. An identified family member shall be notified immediately and shall be required to transport the student, faculty, or staff back home or to a health facility. If transportation is unavailable, the LSPU shall aid to ensure that the student, faculty, or staff is safely transferred to his or her home or to a healthcare facility.

intent: What are the COVID-19 guidelines and protocols for LSPU employees (Regular, Casual, Contract of Service/Job Order)?
response: 10.1. Notice of quarantine (Form LSPU-HSU3) shall be issued by the Health Services Unit of the LSPU Employees respective campuses to those who shall be advised to be under quarantine; 10.2. A minimum of fourteen (14) days quarantine period shall be imposed to suspected person/s; 10.3. Strict implementation of the No Contact Policy shall be observed all-throughout the entire duration of the quarantine; 10.4. The employee shall be reminded that he/she is strictly advised not to go out during the entire duration of the quarantine; 10.5. Only those who are sent or assigned to be on official business or work shall be without deduction on leave credit/s for regular/ casual employees, or be given salary/wages (casual, regular, COs/ Jos) for the prescribed duration of quarantine period. Also, the concerned employee must adhere to the quarantine protocol imposed by the University, Municipal Health Office, City Health Office, Rural Health Unit; 10.6. LSPU employee/s who had been exposed or identified to be a close contact of a COVID-19 positive shall be advised to undergo a strict 14-day home quarantine and shall not be permitted to return to work until he/she had been released a negative RT-PCR (swab) Test result or any equivalent certification/clearance from respective RHU (if applicable), and that of the COVID-19 positive he/she had been exposed to; 10.7. LSPU employees who had been in contact with an LSPU employee considered to be exposed or a close contact of a COVID-19 positive shall be advised to undergo a strict 7-day home quarantine. If after the 7-day quarantine period, the employee developed no flu-like symptoms, he/she shall be permitted to go back to work, requesting clearance from the Health Services Unit of his/ her respective campus. But if the employee developed flu-like symptoms anytime during the 7-day quarantine period, the quarantine period shall be extended to 14 days; 10.8. LSPU employees who had been visiting hospitals on a daily basis/ taking care of someone admitted in a hospital shall not be allowed to report to work without undergoing a strict 14-day home quarantine; 10.9. LSPU employees who had attended funerals of those who have died due to pneumonia, tuberculosis, and other known COVID19 related cause of deaths shall be subjected to a 14-day quarantine; 10.10. LSPU Drivers and other LSPU employees who shall travel on official business or work must furnish the Health Services Unit of their respective campuses with copies of their travel orders or signed memoranda authorizing their travel. They shall be advised by the Health Services Unit as to how many days they shall be on home quarantine, depending on the place where they have traveled, the duration of their stay in a specific place, the number of COVID-19 cases in the place they have visited, among others; 10.11. If an LSPU employee was found out to be positive for COVID19, the University shall immediately report to the LGU where it is located, and shall immediately close for 48 hours to disinfect the whole University; 10.12. Upon return to work, the employee/s who had undergone quarantine shall submit clearance from Municipal Health Office/City Health Office/Rural Health Unit to the university health services unit; 10.13. The employee who are positive with COVID19 shall be permitted to return to work provided that he/she had finished the required days of quarantine of not less than 14 days, supported by a negative RT-PCR (swab) Test; 10.14. The University Health Services Unit must notify the Campus Director, Human Resource and the Accounting Unit for the return to work of the quarantined employee. It shall also be their responsibility to report any health-related concerns and recommendations to the Campus Director and Human Resource Office before implementing them, unless it is considered to be an emergency, one calling for an urgent medical decision.

intent: How can I ensure my child's safety on campus?
response: Universities have dedicated security measures in place, such as surveillance systems, campus police, and emergency response protocols. Additionally, counseling services are available to support students' mental well-being.

intent: What are the housing options available for students?
response: Most universities offer on-campus dormitories or apartments for students to live in. These accommodations are typically supervised and provide a supportive community. Some universities also have partnerships with nearby off-campus housing providers.

intent: What financial aid opportunities are available for students?
response: Universities often provide various financial aid options, including scholarships, grants, work-study programs, and student loans. Students can explore these options by contacting the university's financial aid office and completing the necessary application forms.

intent: What academic programs and majors does the university offer?
response: he university offers a wide range of academic programs across different disciplines. These can include engineering, business, humanities, sciences, arts, and more. It's important to research the university's website or contact the admissions office for specific program details.

intent: What extracurricular activities and clubs are available on campus?
response: Universities offer a wide array of extracurricular activities and clubs to cater to students' interests. These can include sports teams, cultural organizations, academic clubs, music ensembles, student government, and more. The university's website or student affairs office can provide details on specific clubs available.

intent: What support services are in place to assist students with their studies?
response: Universities typically have writing labs, and academic advisors who can provide guidance and support to students. Additionally, professors often have office hours where students can seek additional help or clarification on course material.

intent: How does the university promote a diverse and inclusive campus environment?
response: Universities strive to create a welcoming and inclusive campus environment through various initiatives. intent: When should I start the college enrollment process?
response: It's recommended to start the process during your junior year of high school.

intent: How do I choose the right college or university?
response: Research and consider factors like academic programs, campus culture, location, size, cost, and opportunities for your desired career path.

intent: What are the admission requirements for colleges?
response: Admission requirements vary but typically include high school transcripts, standardized test scores (such as the SAT or ACT), letters of recommendation, and a personal statement or essay.

intent: What standardized tests are required for college admission?
response: The most common standardized tests for college admission are the SAT and ACT. However, some colleges may have test-optional policies.

intent: How do I apply for financial aid and scholarships?
response: Complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) to apply for federal aid. Research and apply for scholarships through various sources like colleges, organizations, and online databases.

intent: What is the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA)?
response: The FAFSA is a form that determines your eligibility for federal financial aid programs, such as grants, loans, and work-study opportunities.

intent: What is the CSS Profile, and when is it required?
response: The CSS Profile is an additional financial aid application required by some colleges and universities to gather more detailed information about your finances. It is used to determine eligibility for non-federal financial aid.

intent: What documents do I need for the college application process?
response: Commonly required documents include high school transcripts, standardized test scores, letters of recommendation, a personal statement or essay, and any supplemental materials specific to the college.

intent: How do I request recommendation letters?
response: Approach teachers, counselors, or mentors who know you well and can speak to your abilities and character. Request letters politely, providing them with necessary information and deadlines.

intent: Can I apply to multiple colleges at once?
response: Yes, you can apply to multiple colleges simultaneously using their respective application processes

intent: What is early decision/early action, and should I consider it?
response: Early decision is a binding agreement, while early action is non-binding. Both allow you to apply earlier than the regular deadline. Consider early options if you have a strong preference for a particular college.

intent: What is the difference between a liberal arts college and a university?
response: Liberal arts colleges primarily focus on undergraduate education and offer a broad-based curriculum. Universities offer a range of undergraduate and graduate programs, including professional schools.

intent: How do I arrange a campus visit or college tour?
response: Contact the college's admissions office to schedule a campus visit or check their website for available tour options. Many colleges also offer virtual tours.

intent: How do I prepare for college interviews?
response: Research the college, practice answering common interview questions, and prepare questions to ask the interviewer. Present yourself professionally and demonstrate your interest and qualifications.

intent: What should I include in my college application essay?
response: The essay should be a personal and compelling narrative that highlights your experiences, values, and aspirations. It should demonstrate your writing skills and provide insight into your character.

intent: What is the deadline for submitting college applications?
response: Deadlines vary by college and can range from as early as November to as late as February or March. It's crucial to check the specific deadlines for each college you're applying to.

intent: How long does it take to hear back from colleges?
response: The timeline varies, but most colleges aim to release admission decisions by April. Some colleges may provide early decisions as early as December or January.

intent: Can I change my major after enrolling in college?
response: Yes, many colleges allow students to change their major after enrollment. However, it's essential to understand any specific requirements or limitations of the college you attend.

intent: What are the next steps after being accepted to a college?
response: After acceptance, you will need to review your financial aid package, submit an enrollment deposit, complete any required forms, and prepare for the transition to college.

intent: How do I secure my spot and enroll in a college?
response: To secure your spot, you typically need to submit an enrollment deposit by the specified deadline. This confirms your intention to attend the college.

intent: What is the difference between early action and regular decision?
response: Early action is a non-binding early application process, while regular decision is the standard application process with a later deadline. Early action provides an earlier admission decision.

intent: Can I defer my admission to a college?
response: Some colleges allow admitted students to defer their enrollment for a year, but policies vary by institution. Contact the college's admissions office to inquire about their deferral process.

intent: How do I calculate my high school GPA for college applications?
response: High school GPAs are typically calculated on a 4.0 scale based on your grades in core academic subjects. Contact your high school counselor for assistance in calculating your GPA.

intent: What are the different types of financial aid available for college students?
response: Financial aid can include grants, scholarships, loans, and work-study programs. Grants and scholarships are typically "free" money, while loans need to be repaid.

intent: How can I find scholarships specific to my field of study?
response: Research online scholarship databases, inquire with your high school's guidance office, explore professional organizations related to your field, and check with the colleges you're applying to for specific scholarships.

intent: Do colleges require interviews for admission?
response: Not all colleges require interviews for admission, but some may offer them as an optional or required component of the application process. Check with the individual colleges for their policies.

intent: Can I apply to college as an undecided major?
response: Yes, many colleges allow students to apply as undecided or undeclared majors. It's common for students to explore different academic paths during their first year or two of college.

intent: What is the difference between a public and private college?
response: Public colleges are funded by the government and often have lower tuition for in-state students. Private colleges are privately funded and typically have higher tuition, but they may offer more financial aid.

intent: What is the Common Application, and how does it work?
response: The Common Application is an online application platform used by over 900 colleges and universities. It allows you to apply to multiple participating colleges using a single application.

intent: What should I do if I'm placed on a college's waitlist?
response: If you're waitlisted, you can choose to accept a spot on the waitlist and provide any additional information or updates that might strengthen your application. It's also important to have a backup plan by accepting admission at another college.

intent: Is it necessary to visit a college before applying?
response: While not mandatory, visiting a college can give you a better sense of the campus environment, facilities, and student life. It can help you make an informed decision when choosing a college.

intent: How do I determine if a college is a good fit for me?
response: Consider factors such as academic programs, location, campus culture, size, cost, resources, and extracurricular opportunities. Researching colleges, talking to current students, and visiting campuses can help you determine if it's a good fit.

intent: Are there any specific requirements for international students applying to college?
response: International students typically need to provide additional documentation, such as proof of English language proficiency, financial documentation, and a passport. Each college may have specific requirements, so check their international admissions guidelines.

intent: Can I transfer from one college to another?
response: Yes, it's possible to transfer from one college to another. Transfer admission requirements and credit transfer policies vary, so research and consult with the colleges you're interested in.

intent: What should I do if I'm not happy with my college choices?
response: If you're not satisfied with your college choices, you can consider appealing your admissions decision, exploring transfer options, or taking a gap year to reconsider your options.

intent: What are the benefits of attending a community college before transferring to a four-year university?
response: Attending a community college before transferring can provide cost savings, smaller class sizes, academic support, and an opportunity to explore different subjects before committing to a four-year institution

intent: What is a college's retention rate, and why is it important?
response: A college's retention rate refers to the percentage of students who continue their studies at the same institution from year to year. A higher retention rate generally indicates student satisfaction and support services.

intent: How do I evaluate the reputation and ranking of a college?
response: You can consider college rankings by reputable sources like U.S. News & World Report, but also evaluate factors such as graduation rates, faculty qualifications, research opportunities, alumni outcomes, and student satisfaction.

intent: Can I take a gap year before starting college?
response: Yes, many colleges allow students to take a gap year before enrolling. It's important to communicate with the college and have a plan for how you will spend your gap year.

intent: Are there resources available for students with disabilities in college?
response: Yes, colleges are required to provide accommodations and support services for students with disabilities. Contact the college's disability services office to discuss your specific needs.

intent: How do I choose the right major for me?
response: Explore your interests, skills, and long-term career goals. Research different majors, talk to academic advisors and professionals in the fields you're considering, and take relevant courses to help you decide.

intent: What are the costs associated with college beyond tuition?
response: In addition to tuition, consider expenses like housing, meal plans, textbooks, supplies, transportation, health insurance, and personal expenses. Create a budget to understand the total cost of attending college.

intent: What is the difference between a bachelor's degree and an associate's degree?
response: A bachelor's degree typically requires four years of full-time study and offers a broader education in a specific field. An associate's degree is usually completed in two years and provides foundational knowledge in a subject area.

intent: What is the student-faculty ratio, and why does it matter?

intent: What rights do freshmen with disabilities have when enrolling in college?
response: Freshmen with disabilities have the right to reasonable accommodations and support under the Magna Carta for Persons with Disabilities (PWDs). This law ensures equal access to education for PWDs and mandates educational institutions to provide necessary adjustments and modifications to accommodate their needs.

intent: How can I request a Transcript of Records?
response: You can request a Transcript of Records by contacting the school's registrar's office or academic records department.

intent: What documents or information do I need to provide to request a Transcript of Records?
response: You may need to provide your full name, student identification number, dates of enrollment, and any other identification or verification details requested by the school.

intent: Is there a fee associated with requesting a Transcript of Records?
response: Yes, there may be a fee for obtaining a Transcript of Records. You can inquire about the fee amount and payment methods from the school.

intent: How long does it take to process a Transcript of Records request?
response: The processing time can vary depending on the school. It's best to ask the school about their expected timeline for issuing the Transcript of Records.

intent: Can I request multiple copies of the Transcript of Records?
response: Yes, you can inquire about the process and any additional fees for obtaining multiple copies of the Transcript of Records.

intent: What format will the Transcript of Records be provided in?
response: The Transcript of Records is usually provided as a printed document on official school letterhead. However, some schools may also offer electronic versions or PDFs.

intent: Can the Transcript of Records be sent directly to another institution or organization?
response: Yes, you can ask the school if they provide the option to send the Transcript of Records directly to another institution or organization. They may have specific procedures for this.

intent: Can I request an official Transcript of Records with a school seal?
response: Most schools provide official Transcripts of Records with a school seal. You can confirm this with the school.

intent: What is the validity period of the Transcript of Records?
response: Transcripts of Records are typically considered valid indefinitely. However, it's always a good idea to confirm with the receiving institution or organization if they have any specific requirements or expiration dates.

intent: Are there any specific instructions for requesting a Transcript of Records for international purposes?
response: If you need the Transcript of Records for international purposes, you can ask the school if they have any specific instructions or additional documentation requirements for international transcript requests.

response: You can inquire if the school can provide a Transcript of Records for a specific academic year, semester, or a selected set of courses.

response: The Transcript of Records will typically display the grades or marks earned for each course or subject taken during your enrollment at the school.

intent: Can I request an accessible format of my TOR if typing is difficult for me?

intent: Can I authorize someone to claim my TOR on my behalf if I struggle with typing?

They will guide you through the process and may require written authorization or specific documentation.

intent: Can someone else claim my TOR on my behalf?

intent: What should I do if there is an error or discrepancy in my TOR?

They will provide you with the necessary information regarding fees, required forms, and any specific authorization requirements.
